abstract_sentences.1: Relation extraction has been widely used for finding unknown relational facts from the plain text.
abstract_sentences.2: Most existing methods focus on exploiting mono-lingual data for relation extraction, ignoring massive information from the texts in various languages.
abstract_sentences.3: To address this issue, we introduce a multi-lingual neural relation extraction framework, which employs monolingual attention to utilize the information within mono-lingual texts and further proposes cross-lingual attention to consider the information consistency and complementarity among cross-lingual texts.
abstract_sentences.4: Experimental results on real-world datasets show that our model can take advantage of multi-lingual texts and consistently achieve significant improvements on relation extraction as compared with baselines.

body_sentences.6: com/thunlp/MNRE  1 Introduction  People build many large-scale knowledge bases (KBs) to store structured knowledge about the real world, such as Wikidata1 and DBpedia2.
body_sentences.7: KBs are playing an important role in many AI and NLP applications such as information retrieval and question answering.
body_sentences.8: The facts in KBs are typically organized in the form of triplets, e.g., (New York, CityOf, United States).
body_sentences.9:
Since existing KBs are far from complete and new facts are growing infinitely, meanwhile manual annotation of these knowledge is time-consuming and

body_sentences.11: Among various methods for relation extraction, distant supervision is the most promising approach (Mintz et al., 2009; Riedel et al., 2010; Hoffmann et al., 2011; Surdeanu et al., 2012), which can automatically generate training instances via aligning KBs and texts to address the issue of lacking supervised data.

body_sentences.14: To address the wrong labelling issue of distant supervision data, Lin et al.
body_sentences.15: (2016) further employ sentence-level attention mechanism in neural relation extraction, and achieves the state-of-the-art performance.
body_sentences.16: However, most RE systems concentrate on extracting relational facts frommono-lingual data.
body_sentences.17: In fact, people describe knowledge about the world using various languages.
body_sentences.18: And people speaking different languages also share similar knowledge about the world due to the similarities of human experiences and human cognitive systems.

For instance, though New York and United States are expressed as纽约 and美国 respectively in Chinese, both Americans and Chinese share the fact that “New York is a city of USA.”
It is straightforward to build mono-lingual RE systems separately for each single language.
body_sentences.20: But if so, it won’t be able to take full advantage of diverse information hidden in the data of various languages.
body_sentences.21: Multi-lingual data will benefit relation extraction for the following two reasons: 1.

body_sentences.26: It is thus non-trivial to locate and learn these relational patterns from complicated sentences for relation extraction.
body_sentences.27: Fortunately, a relational fact is usually expressed with certain patterns in various languages, and the correspondence of these patterns among languages is substantially consistent.
body_sentences.28: The pattern consistency among languages provides us augmented clues to enhance relational pattern learning for relation extraction.
body_sentences.31: From our experiment data, we also find that 42.2% relational facts in English data and 41.6% ones in Chinese data are unique.
body_sentences.32: Moreover, for nearly half of relations, the number of sentences expressing relational facts of these relations varies a lot in different languages.
body_sentences.33: It is thus straightforward that the texts in different languages can be complementary to each other, especially from those resource-rich languages to resource-poor languages, and improve the overall performance of relation extraction.
body_sentences.34: To take full consideration of these issues, we propose Multi-lingual Attention-based Neural Relation Extraction (MNRE).
body_sentences.35: We first employ a convolutional neural network (CNN) to embed the relational patterns in sentences into real-valued vectors.

body_sentences.38: Finally, we classify relations according to the global vector aggregated from all sentence vectors weighted by mono-lingual attention and cross-lingual attention.
body_sentences.39: In experiments, we build training instances via distant supervision by aligning Wikidata with Chinese Baidu Baike and English Wikipedia articles and evaluate the performance of relation extraction in both English and Chinese.

body_sentences.42: 2 Related Work  Recent years KBs have been widely used on various AI and NLP applications.
body_sentences.43: As an important approach to enrich KBs, relation extraction from plain text has attracted many research interests.
body_sentences.44: Relation extraction typically classifies each entity pair into various relation types according to supporting sentences that the both entities appear, which needs human-labelled relationspecific training instances.
body_sentences.45: Many works have been invested to relation extraction including kernelbased model (Zelenko et al., 2003), embeddingbased model (Gormley et al., 2015), CNN-based models (Zeng et al., 2014; dos Santos et al., 2015), and RNN-based model (Socher et al., 2012).
body_sentences.46: Nevertheless, these RE systems are insufficient due to the lack of training data.
body_sentences.47: To address this issue, Mintz et al.
body_sentences.48: (2009) align plain text with Freebase to automatically generate training instances following the distant supervision assumption.
body_sentences.49: To further alleviate the wrong labelling problem, Riedel et al.
body_sentences.50: (2010) model distant supervision for relation extraction as a multiinstance single-label learning problem, and Hoffmann et al.
body_sentences.52: (2012) regard it as a multi-instance multi-label learning problem.
body_sentences.54: (2015) attempt to connect neural networks with distant supervision following the expressed-at-least-once assumption.
body_sentences.56: (2016) further utilize sentence-level attention mechanism to consider all informative sentences jointly.
body_sentences.57: Most existing RE systems are absorbed in extracting relations from mono-lingual data, ignoring massive information lying in texts from multiple languages.
body_sentences.58: In this area, Faruqui and Kumar (2015) present a language independent open domain relation extraction system, and Verga et al.
body_sentences.59: (2015) further employ Universal Schema to combine OpenIE and link-prediction perspective for multi-lingual relation extraction.
body_sentences.60: Both the works focus on multi-lingual transfer learning and learn a predictive model on a new language for existing KBs, by leveraging unified representation learning for cross-lingual entities.
body_sentences.61: Different from these works, our framework aims to jointly model the texts in multiple languages to enhance relation extraction with distant supervision.
body_sentences.62: To the best of our knowledge, this is the first effort to multi-lingual neural relation extraction.
body_sentences.63: The scope of multi-lingual analysis has been widely considered in many tasks besides relation extraction, such as sentiment analysis (Boiy and Moens, 2009), cross-lingual document summarization (Boudin et al., 2011), information retrieval in Web search (Dong et al., 2014) and so on.

body_sentences.100: 3.2 Multi-lingual Attention  To exploit the information of the sentences from all languages, our model adopts two kinds of attention mechanisms for multi-lingual relation extraction, including: (1) the mono-lingual attention which selects the informative sentences within one language and (2) the cross-lingual attention which measures the pattern consistency among languages.

body_sentences.103: Hence we adopt different mono-lingual attentions to deemphasize those noisy sentences within each language.

body_sentences.138: 4.1 Datasets and Evaluation Metrics  We generate a new multi-lingual relation extraction dataset to evaluate our MNRE framework.
body_sentences.139: Without loss of generality, the experiments focus on relation extraction from two languages including English and Chinese.
body_sentences.140: In this dataset, the Chinese instances are generated by aligning Chinese Baidu Baike with Wikidata, and the English instances are generated by aligning English Wikipedia articles with Wikidata.
body_sentences.141: The relational facts of Wikidata in this dataset are divided into three parts for training, validation and testing respectively.
body_sentences.142: There are 176 relations including a special relation NA indicating there is no relation between entities.
body_sentences.143: Andwe set both validation and testing sets for Chinese and English parts contain the same facts.
body_sentences.144: We list the statistics about the dataset in Table 2.
body_sentences.145: We follow previous works (Mintz et al., 2009) and investigate the performance of RE systems using the held-out evaluation, by comparing the relational facts discovered by RE systems from the testing set with those facts in KB.
body_sentences.146: The evaluation method assumes that if a RE system accurately finds more relational facts in KBs from the testing set, it will achieve better performance for relation extraction.
body_sentences.147: The held-out evaluation provides an approximate measure of RE performance without time-consuming human evaluation.
body_sentences.148: In experiments, we report the precision/recall curves as the evaluation metric.
body_sentences.149: 4.2 Experimental Settings  We tune the parameters of our MNRE framework by grid searching using validation set.
body_sentences.150: For training, we set the iteration number over all the training data as 15.
body_sentences.151: The best models were selected by early stopping using the evaluation results on the validation set.
body_sentences.152: In Table 3 we show the best setting of all parameters used in our experiments.

body_sentences.198: 5 Conclusion  In this paper, we introduce a neural relation extraction framework with multi-lingual attention to take pattern consistency and complementarity among multiple languages into consideration.
body_sentences.199: We evaluate our framework onmulti-lingual relation extraction task, and the results show that our framework can effectively model relation patterns among languages and achieve state-of-the-art results.
body_sentences.200: We will explore the following directions as future work: (1) In this paper, we only consider sentence-level multi-lingual attention for relation extraction.
body_sentences.201: In fact, we find that the word alignment information may be also helpful for capturing relation patterns.
body_sentences.202: Hence, the word-level multi-lingual attention, which may discover implicit alignments between words in multiple languages, will further improve multi-lingual relation extraction.
body_sentences.203:
We will explore the effectiveness of word-level multilingual attention for relation extraction as our fu-
ture work.
body_sentences.204: (2) MNRE can be flexibly implemented in the scenario of multiple languages, and this paper focuses on two languages of English and Chinese.
body_sentences.205: In future, we will extendMNRE to more languages and explore its significance.
